results.title: A Career in hotels and restaurants
results.brief_description: The hotel and restaurant business as a career: a visit by two young people to a hotel where the manager greets them and shows them all the departments, explaining the background for every job and the prospects for entrants. Encourages school leavers to ask if they too can visit a local hotel and look behind the scenes.

results.title: A Career in commercial television
results.creator_credit: Artransa Park Studios and Tony Wellington
results.brief_description: Looks at the administrative, engineering and production aspects of commercial television, concentrating in particular on production. Stresses the limited opportunities available in this field and how most people in production commence work at the bottom rung of the production ladder. Narrated by Roger Climpson. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: A Career in bricklaying
results.creator_credit: Academy Film Productions and Ronald Mason
results.brief_description: This film emphasizes the positive aspects of work in bricklaying. As in most career films the less-favourable side of the work is omitted. Bricklayers are shown learning the trade, and the application of bricklaying skills is depicted in various constructions including ornamental brickwork, arches, and brickwork in high-rise buildings. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: A Career in accountancy
results.creator_credit: Garry Blackledge, Artransa Park Studios and Richard Wallace
results.brief_description: Looks at three young people working in the field of accountancy and notes their reasons for choosing accountancy as a career as well as the range of options open to them. Also considers the role played by the Australian Society of Accountants. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: A Canterbury tale
results.creator_credit: Rank Film Productions, Archers Film Productions, Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger
results.brief_description: A puzzle when it first appeared, but now hailed as one of Powell and Pressburger’s most suggestive and profound explorations of Englishness, this is a modern-day pilgrimage. Four people, uprooted by the war, are drawn towards Canterbury - and discover what they couldn’t find in peacetime. Described by Derek Jarman as English culture dealt with mythically in a very strange way. Stars Eric Portman, Sheila Sim, and Dennis Price.

results.title: A Call from Malaysia
results.creator_credit: United Nations Television and Gilbert Lauzun
results.brief_description: We follow the efforts of a young Sarawak villager as he learns to participate in broadcasting, telephony, aviation and other modern occupations required in Malaysia (1967). Six million people living on countless islands and one large peninsula are now united in the Federation of Malaysia and the agencies of the United Nations are at work helping them build a modern and effective country.

results.title: A Calendar of dreamings: Aboriginal artists of Central Australia
results.brief_description: This film depicts mythological aspects of Aboriginal life in the western McDonald Range area of Central Australia with specific reference to three tribal groups. It deals with ‘water dreaming’ as well as various myths and legends related to the present situation of the Aboriginals. The film incorporates approximately 44 paintings by Central Aborigines using an ancient technique known as sand painting. A study of the meanings of the symbols and signs used in Australian aboriginal paintings. Legends of the Aboriginal’s Dreamtime are passed down to the younger member by their elders in ritual ceremonies. Narrated by John Bell, edited by Phil Noyce.

results.title: A Calcutta Christmas
results.creator_credit: Denise Haslem, Film Australia, SBS Independent and Maree Delofski
results.brief_description: Tucked away in the middle of the noisy polluted ‘city of joy’, Calcutta, is Tollygunge Home - a haven of peace and quiet for 35 elderly Christian Anglo-Indian residents. During the British colonial rule, British men were encouraged to marry Indian women in order that their children would help further Britain’s imperial interest in India. Children of these marriages became known as Anglo-Indians (or in earlier years, Eurasians) and lived a fairly wealthy lifestyle during the British colonial years of the late 19th century. However as time went on, racism and discrimination began to seep in and Anglo-Indians then found themselves in limbo - neither Indian nor British. After India won independence in 1947, two-thirds of the Anglo-Indian community emigrated to other parts of the British Commonwealth such as Britain, Canada and Australia. Those left behind became dislocated from their families and their living conditions declined quite dramatically. Tollygunge Home is financed by the East India Charitable Fund and managed by a committee of volunteers for these Anglo-Indian residents and this documentary explores their thoughts, memories and lifestyle through interviews. Shows them preparing for Christmas day celebrations in the traditional British way and highlights the personal interactions which take place, not only the anger, jealousies and loneliness but also the friendships, the bonding and love which holds them together as a community. Narrated by Rachel Blake.

results.title: A Bus for us
results.creator_credit: Len Chatwin, ONF | NFB and Rex Tasker
results.brief_description: After repeated attempts to obtain service from the public transportation authorities, these suburban Ottawa residents finally decided to do it themselves.

results.title: A Burn's best friend
results.creator_credit: British Petroleum and St John Ambulance Australia
results.brief_description: This film deals with burns caused by sun, chemicals, steam and fire, stressing that COLD WATER is the best first aid treatment where injury is susceptible to infection. It explains the medical principle behind this treatment.
